review.title: A Natural Language Query Interface for Searching Personal Information on Smartwatches
review.abstract: Currently, personal assistant systems, run on smartphones and use natural language interfaces. However, these systems rely mostly on the web for finding information. Mobile and wearable devices can collect an enormous amount of contextual personal data such as sleep and physical activities. These information objects and their applications are known as quantified-self, mobile health or personal informatics, and they can be used to provide a deeper insight into our behavior. To our knowledge, existing personal assistant systems do not support all types of quantified-self queries. In response to this, we have undertaken a user study to analyze a set of "textual questions/queries" that users have used to search their quantified-self or mobile health data. Through analyzing these questions, we have constructed a light-weight natural language based query interface, including a text parser algorithm and a user interface, to process the users' queries that have been used for searching quantified-self information. This query interface has been designed to operate on small devices, i.e. smartwatches, as well as augmenting the personal assistant systems by allowing them to process end users' natural language queries about their quantified-self data.

sections.heading: A. User Study
sections.text: Goal: To implement a query interface based on personal data, we need to understand: (i) what types of knowledge do users seek from their available personal data (on their mobile or portable devices)? (ii) How do users ask to search for the information they want? To answer both questions, we have a survey on MTurk.Participants: For the user study, Bargas-Avila and Hornbæk [13] recommend focusing not only on users who are familiar with a system for a user study, but also on users who are not familiar with the system. Therefore, our eligibility criteria include participants who own smartphones, but they do not necessarily need to be familiar with QA systems. Survey results show that users who are not familiar with QA technologies raise several interesting questions. This insight allows for better quantification of final requests and even covers queries for the sensors that do not yet exist, such as a sensor that does not need to be washed or a cloth.

sections.heading: B. Content Analysis and Query Construction
sections.text: We have performed two types of analyses of the data collected by MTurk: qualitative analyses using thematic analyses and quantitative analyses using linguistic analyses. We then construct the query parser and its user interface based on both analyses.

sections.heading: 2) Linguistic Analysis
sections.text: To perform the quantitative analysis, we asked the questions implicitly, deleted punctuations and stopped terms, and determined the frequency of the words in the collected queries; the thematic analysis shows the limitations of the queries and their categories; the results show that there are four categories of words: (i) question words, (ii) words that represent a temporal term of the query; (ii) words that represent the subject of the query, e.g. sleep, walking, and (iv) aggregation words. Our algorithm also uses verb tense for the query construction, which will be explained later. sections.heading: 3) Tokenization & Lexicon Extraction Algorithm
sections.text: Many of the existing NLP systems [8,9,10] create a "parse tree" from the given query, which is in text format. Parse tree creation is a mathematically complex process, but can be used to handle a variety of texts. However, our approach does not have to cover a wide range of questions. Instead, we focus on QA queries. Furthermore, smartwatches cannot deal with existing parse tree creation algorithms, which usually comprise more than one sentence.
